headline: /C O R R E C T I O N -- Jeppesen ForeFlight/
summary: The original innovators of aviation technology are back in a big way. Today, Jeppesen ForeFlight announced its launch as a new digital aviation entity, backed by Thoma Bravo, a leading software investment firm. The company has completed its separation from Boeing and sale to Thoma Bravo in an all-cash transaction valued at $10.55 billion. Brad Surak, who previously led the Digital Aviation Solutions business at Boeing, will lead Jeppesen ForeFlight as Chief Executive Officer.

Brad Surak, who previously led the Digital Aviation Solutions business at Boeing, will lead Jeppesen ForeFlight as Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Amazon’s OpenAI Deal Is Boosting AI Stocks. The Rest of the Market Is Struggling.
summary: Stocks linked to the artificial intelligence rally were pretty much the only winners during Monday’s session. The Dow fell 410 points, or 0.9%. The S&P 500 was down 0.2%, but only 67 of its members were rising.

headline: Machinists’ strike barely impacts Boeing’s Q3 revenue of $23.3B
summary: However, the St. Louis-area plants’ work stoppage delayed deliveries of the F-15EX aircraft and could impact its financial recovery if the strike continues. On the commercial side, the company is awaiting U.S. approval for its acquisition of Spirit AeroSystems.

headline: Quicker Boeing deliveries help Ryanair boost profit, traffic forecast
summary: STORY: Ryanair profits flew up 42% in the first six months of the year.The budget airline reported a forecast-beating $2.96 billion on Monday (November 3).That was well up from the same period last year and above analyst projections.Average fares also grew by 13% year-on-year.Ryanair also raised its passenger traffic forecast Monday.It cited earlier than expected Boeing deliveries and strong first-half demand.The carrier said it cautiously expects to recover all of last year's 7% average fare decline in the financial year to March end.It further added this should lead to what it called 'reasonable' full-year net profit growth.Ryanair expects to fly 207 million passengers to end-March - up by a million from a previous forecast.The uptick comes after the airline received 23 new MAX 8 aircraft from Boeing.Ryanair said it is confident of receiving the six remaining MAX 8 aircraft from an order that had suffered long delays by February.Shares were down over 2% in early Monday trade.

raw.headline: Quicker Boeing deliveries help Ryanair boost profit, traffic forecast
raw.summary: STORY: Ryanair profits flew up 42% in the first six months of the year.The budget airline reported a forecast-beating $2.96 billion on Monday (November 3).That was well up from the same period last year and above analyst projections.Average fares also grew by 13% year-on-year.Ryanair also raised its passenger traffic forecast Monday.It cited earlier than expected Boeing deliveries and strong first-half demand.The carrier said it cautiously expects to recover all of last year's 7% average fare decline in the financial year to March end.It further added this should lead to what it called 'reasonable' full-year net profit growth.Ryanair expects to fly 207 million passengers to end-March - up by a million from a previous forecast.The uptick comes after the airline received 23 new MAX 8 aircraft from Boeing.Ryanair said it is confident of receiving the six remaining MAX 8 aircraft from an order that had suffered long delays by February.Shares were down over 2% in early Monday trade.

headline: Ryanair CEO O'Leary on Boeing 737 Max, Passenger Growth
summary: Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary talks with Bloomberg after reporting profit after tax which rose to 1.72 billion ($2 billion) in the second quarter from 1.43 billion the previous year. The Irish budget airline also said it expects to exceed its passenger growth target for the full year as the airline receives aircraft early from Boeing Co. and demand for travel remains strong.

headline: Boeing (BA): Assessing Valuation Following a Recent Drop and Ongoing Recovery Signals
summary: Boeing (BA) shares have caught the attention of many investors after a recent event impacted its stock performance. Traders are watching to see whether this shift signals a longer-term change or just short-term volatility for the aerospace leader. See our latest analysis for Boeing. Boeing's share price recently took a hit following news events, dropping nearly 10% over the past week.
